conclusion: To determine whether the distance fallen during the 10 to 15 seconds interval is greater than or less than 75 meters, we need to calculate the area under the velocity-time (v-t) graph for that interval.
The area under a velocity-time graph represents the distance traveled.
The interval we are interested in is from t = 10 seconds to t = 15 seconds.
At t = 10 seconds, the velocity is approximately 20 m/s.
At t = 15 seconds, the velocity is approximately 10 m/s.
The graph appears to be linear between these two points.

premise: The graph is linear between t = 10 and t = 15 seconds.
conclusion: The area under the graph between t = 10 seconds and t = 15 seconds can be calculated as the area of a trapezoid.
Formula for the area of a trapezoid: Area = 1/2 × (Base₁ + Base₂) × Height

premise: Base₁ = 20 m/s, Base₂ = 10 m/s, Height = 5 seconds
The calculated area under the v-t graph for the interval from t = 10 seconds to t = 15 seconds is 75 meters.
conclusion: The distance fallen during the 10 to 15 seconds interval is exactly 75 meters.
